title: Senator John Hoeven Bought Up Netflix, Kontoor Stock
text:
Text size

Senator John Hoeven recently disclosed financial transactions in publicly traded stocks.

The North Dakota Republican bought both Netflix stock (ticker: NFLX) and Kontoor Brands stock (KTB), his first transactions in either name this year. Hoeven made the disclosures in a form he filed with the Secretary of the Senate on Sept. 25.

In response to a request for comment, Hoeven’s office provided the statement: “Senator Hoeven’s stock trades were made in consultation with his financial advisers and in accordance with Senate regulations and reporting requirements.”

Hoeven bought $50,001 to $100,000 of Netflix stock on Sept. 24. Specific values aren’t required for disclosure, only ranges. The senator’s 2018 disclosure form shows that he didn’t own any shares of the videostreaming giant at the end of that year.

Editor's Choice

Netflix’s stock has had a reversal of fortune this year. After logging a 39.4% rise last year, shares continued surging, setting a 2019 intraday high of $385.99 on May 1, representing a year-to-date gain at that point of 44.2%. But fears of rival services from Walt Disney (DIS) and Apple (AAPL) and a setback in subscriber numbers have hammered Netflix’s stock since. Shares now sport a loss of 1.7% so far this year. By comparison, the S&P 500 sports a year-to-date rise of 18.1%. We noted that at least one analyst is bullish on Netflix stock, although we have our doubts.

Hoeven bought $15,001 to $50,000 of Kontoor stock on Sept. 24. Kontoor, which spun off from VF (VFC) this past May, owns the Wrangler and Lee brands of jeans. VF shareholders received one Kontoor share for every seven VF shares they owned.

Hoeven is adding to his Kontoor position with the purchase. He owned VF stock valued between $250,001 and $500,000 at the end of 2018, and he hasn’t sold any since.

Kontoor stock closed at $38.60 on May 23, its first day of trading publicly after the distribution. Shares have slipped since, closing at $34.52 on Friday.

Inside Scoop is a regular Barron’s feature covering stock transactions by corporate executives and board members—so-called insiders—as well as large shareholders, politicians, and other prominent figures. Due to their insider status, these investors are required to disclose stock trades with the Securities and Exchange Commission or other regulatory groups.

description: The North Dakota Republican marked his first transactions this year in the streaming giant and the jeans maker.
